questions.text: The inner layer of the fallopian tube is covered by:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Ciliated columnar epithelium

Explanation:

  • The inner lining of the fallopian tube (also called the mucosa) is composed of ciliated columnar epithelium, which helps in the transport of the ovum toward the uterus through rhythmic ciliary movements.

Histology of the Fallopian Tube

Layer

Structure

Function

Mucosa

Ciliated columnar epithelium with secretory (peg) cells

Helps in ovum transport and secretion of nutrients

Muscularis

Inner circular and outer longitudinal smooth muscle layers

Peristalsis aids in ovum movement

Serosa

Outer peritoneal covering

Provides structural integrity

 

Simple columnar epithelium (Option A): Incorrect because while the fallopian tube has columnar cells, they are primarily ciliated, aiding ovum movement.

Pseudostratified ciliated columnar epithelium (Option B): Incorrect because this type is typically found in the respiratory tract, not the fallopian tube.

Cuboidal epithelium with microvilli (Option D): Incorrect because cuboidal epithelium with microvilli is characteristic of renal tubules, not the fallopian tube.

questions.text: Which of the following organs does this epithelium most likely belong to?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Ureter

Explanation:

The image shows Urothelium, or Transitional Epithelium, a specialized tissue found exclusively in the urinary tract—specifically, the ureter, among the given options.

  • A multilayered epithelium with four to six thick cells that can contract and expand as needed (stretchable epithelium).
  • It is found in the renal pelvis and calyces, the ureter, the urinary bladder, and prostatic urethra.
  • Features:
    • Cells towards the lumen are very large and called umbrella-shaped cells (typical for transitional epithelium).
    • Each cell is attached to the basement membrane by a cytoplasmic extension. The basement membrane is straight.
    • Transitional between stratified squamous and stratified columnar epithelia.
      • Cells at the surface are not squamous.
      • Deepest cells are columnar or cuboidal.
      • Middle layers are made up of polyhedral or pear-shaped cells.
    • Superficial cell layer (lines the lumen): Only fully differentiated layer of the epithelium → Provides an impenetrable barrier between the lumen and the bloodstream.

Incorrect Options:

Option B: Gallbladder is lined by simple columnar epithelium with microvilli.

 Option C: Trachea is lined by pseudostratified ciliated columnar epithelium with goblet cells.

Option D: Intestine is lined by simple columnar epithelium with goblet cells.

questions.text: The area marked by the arrows in the given histopathological image can influence the surrounding cells by:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Paracrine effect

Explanation:

  • The area marked in the image is the Islet of Langerhans, located in the pancreas.

  • These hormones can act locally to influence nearby cells within the islet before reaching systemic circulation — this is known as a paracrine effect.

Paracrine Mechanism in the Islets:

Cell Type

Hormone Secreted

Paracrine Effect On

β cells

Insulin

Inhibits α cells (↓ glucagon)

α cells

Glucagon

Stimulates β cells (↑ insulin)

δ cells

Somatostatin

Inhibits both α and β cells

Portal Vasculature (Option A) - Not involved in direct local cell-to-cell signaling.

Nerve mediated (Option C) - Islet regulation is mostly hormonal, not neural.

Epitheliomesenchymal transition (Option D) - An epithelial-mesenchymal transition (EMT) is a biologic process that allows a polarized epithelial cell, which normally interacts with basement membrane via its basal surface, to undergo multiple biochemical changes that enable it to assume a mesenchymal cell phenotype, which includes enhanced migratory capacity, invasiveness, elevated resistance to apoptosis, and greatly increased production of ECM components.

questions.text: Identify the cell marked in the histological image of the cerebellum shown below:
questions.solution:
Answer: A) Purkinje cells

Explanation:

  • Purkinje cells are large, flask-shaped neurons located in the Purkinje layer of the cerebellar cortex. They have extensive dendritic trees that branch into the molecular layer and receive synaptic inputs from parallel fibers (granule cells).
  • These cells serve as the primary output neurons of the cerebellar cortex, sending inhibitory signals (GABAergic) to the deep cerebellar nuclei.

The cerebellar cortex consists of the following three distinct layers:

Layers of the cerebellar cortex

Molecular (plexiform) layer

Purkinje cell layer

Granular layer

It primarily contains numerous dendritic branches from Purkinje cells, with relatively few widely spaced nerve cells.

It consists of a single row of large flask-shaped cells, the Purkinje cells.

The inner granular layer is made up of many closely packed small granule cells, along with a few larger Golgi cells.

These nerve cells are of two types:

(a) Basket cells

(b) Stellate cells.

The axons of Purkinje cells are the only output from the cerebellar cortex and have an inhibitory effect on the intracerebellar nuclei.

Golgi cells are inhibitory while the granular cells are excitatory.

Among the five types of intrinsic neurons (Basket cells, Stellate cells, Purkinje cells, Granule cells and Golgi cells)- All are inhibitory except granule cells.

 


Incorrect Options:

Basket cells (option B): Small inhibitory interneurons in the molecular layer of the cerebellum. Form synapses on the cell bodies of Purkinje cells, but are not flask-shaped.

Golgi cells (option C): Inhibitory interneurons found in the granule layer. Provide feedback inhibition to granule cells but do not have the distinctive flask shape of Purkinje cells.

Granule cells (option D): The smallest and most numerous neurons in the cerebellum, found in the granule cell layer. They excite Purkinje cells via parallel fibers but are not flask-shaped.

questions.text: Identify the type of cartilage shown in the image below:
questions.solution:
Answer: B) Elastic cartilage

Explanation:

  • The histological image shows numerous branching elastic fibers, which are characteristic of elastic cartilage.
  • Elastic cartilage contains elastic fibers in the extracellular matrix, providing flexibility and resilience.
  • It is found in structures requiring both strength and elasticity, such as:
    • Auricle of the ear
    • Epiglottis
    • Eustachian tube

Types of Cartilage

Characteristic

Hyaline Cartilage (Most Common)

Elastic Cartilage

Fibrocartilage

Matrix appearance

Homogeneous, basophilic

Contains elastic fiber network

Numerous collagen bundles

Chondrocyte arrangement

Groups (cell nests/isogenous groups)

Similar to hyaline

Single rows or isogenous groups

Perichondrium

Present (except in articular cartilage)

Present

Absent

Main fiber type

Type II collagen

Elastic fibers

Type I (primarily) and Type II collagen

Main functions

Structural support, forms articular surfaces

Provides flexibility and resilience

Resists compression and shearing, shock absorption

Examples

Costal cartilage, tracheal rings, articular cartilage

Auricle, epiglottis, auditory tube

Intervertebral discs, menisci

 

Incorrect Options:

Hyaline cartilage (option A): Lacks elastic fibers and appears as a glassy, homogenous matrix. Found in articular surfaces, costal cartilages, trachea, and nasal septum.

Articular cartilage (option C): A specialized type of hyaline cartilage covering joint surfaces. It lacks elastic fibers and has a smooth, glassy appearance.

Fibrocartilage (option D): Contains dense collagen fibers but lacks elastic fibers. Found in intervertebral discs, pubic symphysis, and menisci.

questions.text: The cell marked in the below slide is inhibitory to
questions.solution:
The marked cell is a Purkinje cell, identified by its large cell body and prominent nucleus in the cerebellar cortex. Purkinje cells are inhibitory and use GABA as their neurotransmitter. Their primary function is to inhibit the deep nuclei of the cerebellum, which are responsible for motor coordination and fine-tuning of movements.

Purkinje Cells and Their Inhibitory Role

Feature

Details

Location

Cerebellar cortex (between molecular & granular layers)

Neurotransmitter

GABA (gamma-aminobutyric acid)

Function

Inhibitory regulation of deep cerebellar nuclei

Target

Deep nuclei of cerebellum

Significance

Helps coordinate fine motor control by regulating output from deep cerebellar nuclei

Vestibular nuclei (Option B): Incorrect, as Purkinje cells do send some projections here but do not primarily inhibit them.

Inferior olivary nucleus (Option C): Incorrect, as it provides excitatory input to Purkinje cells, but is not their target.

Basal ganglia (Option D): Incorrect, as Purkinje cells have no direct connection to the basal ganglia.

questions.text: Identify the incorrect match:
questions.solution:
• 1 (Cilia) – These are hair-like projections on the apical surface of columnar epithelial cells, helping in mucus clearance via coordinated movement. Correct
  • 2 (Goblet cells) – These are unicellular mucus-secreting glands dispersed within the pseudostratified columnar epithelium, aiding in airway moisture and protection. Correct
  • 3 (Nuclei of epithelial cells) – The nuclei are at varying levels, creating a pseudostratified appearance. Correct
  • 4 (Incorrectly matched as Lamina Propria) – This label belongs to the epithelial layer, whereas the lamina propria is the connective tissue layer beneath the basement membrane. Incorrect

Pseudostratified Ciliated Columnar Epithelium (Respiratory Epithelium)

Feature

Description

Location

Found in the trachea, bronchi, and nasal cavity.

Cell Types

Ciliated columnar cells, goblet cells, basal cells, and brush cells.

Function

Mucociliary clearance – Cilia move mucus upward, trapping and removing debris.

Lamina Propria

A loose connective tissue layer beneath the epithelium, not part of the epithelial layer.

Pathological Relevance

Loss of cilia function leads to chronic respiratory infections (e.g., in Kartagener syndrome).

1 - Cilia (Option A): Correct, as cilia are present on the epithelial surface.

2 - Goblet cells (Option C): Correct, as goblet cells are present within the pseudostratified epithelium.

3 - Nuclei of epithelial cells (Option D): Correct, as these belong to pseudostratified columnar epithelium.

questions.text: Given below is a histological section of the thyroid gland. Which of the following is secreted by the cell marked ‘X’ in the image?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Calcitonin

Explanation:

The marked structure in the image is a parafollicular (C) cell of the thyroid gland. These cells secrete calcitonin, a hormone involved in calcium homeostasis by reducing blood calcium levels.

Thyroid Gland Histology

Cell Type

Location

Hormone Secreted

Function

Follicular cells

Line the thyroid follicles

Thyroxine (T3, T4)

Regulates metabolism.

Parafollicular (C) cells

Between follicles

Calcitonin

Lowers blood calcium by inhibiting osteoclasts.

Thyroxine (Option A): Incorrect because thyroxine (T3/T4) is secreted by follicular cells, not parafollicular cells.

PTH (Option C): Incorrect because parathyroid hormone (PTH) is secreted by the parathyroid gland, not the thyroid.

Serotonin (Option D): Incorrect because serotonin is a neurotransmitter mainly found in the CNS and enterochromaffin cells, not the thyroid.

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding bones is false?

choices.text: Osteocytes are the major cell type in mature bone
Collagen is synthesized in bone osteoblasts
Calcium phosphate is one of the major inorganic mineral

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Bone mainly contains type 2 collagen

Explanation:

  • Bone primarily contains Type I collagen, not Type II. Type I collagen provides structural support and tensile strength to bones. Type II collagen is mainly found in cartilage, not bone.

Bone Composition and Structure

Component

Function

Cells

Osteoblasts (bone formation), Osteocytes (maintenance), Osteoclasts (resorption)

Collagen Type

Type I collagen is the primary structural protein in bone

Inorganic Component

Hydroxyapatite (Calcium phosphate) provides bone rigidity

Bone Matrix

Composed of organic (collagen and proteins) and inorganic (minerals) components

 

Osteocytes are the major cell type in mature bone (Option A): Correct because osteocytes are the most abundant bone cells, maintaining bone matrix.

Collagen is synthesized in bone by osteoblasts (Option B): Correct because osteoblasts produce Type I collagen, a key component of bone matrix.

Calcium phosphate is one of the major inorganic minerals (Option D): Correct as hydroxyapatite (a form of calcium phosphate) is the main inorganic component of bone.

questions.text: Which type of collagen is present in cartilage?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Type 2 collagen

Explanation:

  • Cartilage is primarily composed of Type 2 collagen, which provides tensile strength and elasticity while resisting compressive forces. It is the main structural protein in hyaline and elastic cartilage.

Types of Collagen and Their Locations

Collagen Type

Location

Function

Type I

Bone, skin, tendons, ligaments, cornea

Provides tensile strength

Type II

Cartilage (hyaline, elastic, fibrocartilage), vitreous humor

Provides resistance to pressure

Type III

Reticular fibers (skin, blood vessels, fetal tissue)

Provides structural support

Type IV

Basement membrane

Forms structural network in BM

 

Type 1 collagen (Option A): Incorrect because it is found in bone, tendons, and skin, not cartilage.

Type 3 collagen (Option C): Incorrect because it is found in reticular fibers of blood vessels and skin, not cartilage.

Type 4 collagen (Option D): Incorrect because it is a non-fibrillar collagen found in basement membranes, not cartilage.

questions.text: What is the type of cartilage present in the histology section given below?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Hyaline cartilage

Explanation:

  • The image shows a glassy, bluish-white matrix with chondrocytes in lacunae
  • Hyaline cartilage is the most common type. It has a glassy, translucent matrix due to the fine collagen fibrils. Chondrocytes (cartilage cells) are scattered throughout the matrix, often appearing in small groups (isogenous groups) within lacunae (spaces).

 

Types of Cartilage

Characteristic

Hyaline Cartilage (Most Common)

Elastic Cartilage (Yellow cartilage) (Option B)

Fibrocartilage (Option D)

Matrix appearance

Homogeneous, basophilic

Contains elastic fiber network

Numerous collagen bundles

Chondrocyte arrangement

Groups (cell nests/isogenous groups)

Similar to hyaline

Single rows or isogenous groups

Perichondrium

Present (except in articular cartilage)

Present

Absent

Main fiber type

Type II collagen

Elastic fibers

Type I (primarily) and Type II collagen

Main functions

Structural support, forms articular surfaces

Provides flexibility and resilience

Resists compression and shearing, shock absorption

Examples

Costal cartilage, tracheal rings, articular cartilage

Auricle, epiglottis, auditory tube

Intervertebral discs, menisci

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

Articular cartilage (Option C): Articular cartilage is a specific type of hyaline cartilage covering the bones' surfaces in synovial joints. While it is a form of hyaline cartilage, the term "articular" refers to its location rather than a different type of cartilage.

questions.text: Identify which of the following structure is a merocrine gland:
questions.solution:
Answer: B) 2

 

Explanation:

Merocrine glands, also referred to as eccrine glands, release their secretions through the cell membrane via exocytosis, without any loss of cellular material. These glands are the most common type of sweat gland, particularly abundant on the palms, soles, and forehead. They are crucial for thermoregulation, as they secrete sweat that evaporates from the skin, helping to cool the body and maintain temperature balance.

 

Feature

Merocrine Glands

Apocrine Glands

Holocrine Glands

Other Name

Eccrine glands

Modified sweat glands (e.g., mammary glands)

-

Cell Membrane Integrity

Membrane is intact

Secretions covered by cell membrane

Entire cell membrane is lost

Secretions

Released without loss of cell membrane

Released along with apical part of cell membrane

Whole cell is lost; becomes sebum

Mechanism of Secretion

Exocytosis

Blebs are formed; secretion is part of the cell membrane

Breakdown of entire cell, organelles become secretions

Examples

Salivary glands

Mammary gland (modified sweat gland)

Sebaceous glands

Function

Thermoregulation (e.g., sweat)

Involved in secretion of milk (in modified sweat glands)

Lubrication of skin (sebum secretion)

questions.text: A 35-year-old patient underwent an endoscopic examination of the gastrointestinal tract due to recurrent abdominal discomfort and altered bowel habits. Identify the arrow-marked structure in the given image.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Brunner's Gland

Explanation:

  • The given histology slide is of duodenum.
  • Identification points:
    • Wall made up of four layers.
    • Mucosa – presence of numerous broad villi lined by simple columnar epithelium with microvilli and goblet cells.
    • Presence of crypts of lieberkuhn
    • Presence of submucous Brunner’s gland.
  • The marked structure by the arrow is of Brunner's gland.

Histology:

Feature

Duodenum

Jejunum

Ileum

Villi

Present

Present

Present

Brunner's Glands

Present

Absent

Absent

Peyer's Patches

Absent

Absent

Present

 

Intestinal Cells of Kajal (Option B): Incorrect term (likely a misinterpretation of interstitial cells of Cajal, which regulate gut motility).

Crypts of Lieberkühn (Option C): Present in the duodenum but are located in the mucosa, whereas Brunner’s glands are in the submucosa.

Peyer’s Patch (Option D): Found in the ileum, not the duodenum.

questions.text: The given histology image is of?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Glomerulus

Explanation:

  • The structure of the histological image given is of the kidney showing a glomerulus by proximal convoluted tubules (PCT), and distal convoluted tubules (DCT).

 

Leydig cells of the testis (Option A):

  • Leydig cells are found between the seminiferous tubules in the interstitial tissue of the testis.
  • They are larger than the neighboring cells and have a distinct morphology.
  • Their cytoplasm is often eosinophilic.
  • The cells typically have a single, large, central nucleus.

 

Pancreatic islet cells (Option B):

  • Islet cells have a large, round nucleus and a lightly-stained cytoplasm.
  • Islet cells are typically arranged in groups, with different cell types clustered together.

 

Hassall's corpuscles (Option C):

  • These structures are located in the medulla of the thymus gland.
  • They are composed of reticular epithelial cells arranged in a concentric fashion with central degenerating eosinophilic matter.
  • The cells in each layer are tightly packed, forming a flattened, disc-like shape.
  • The blue dots are lymphocytes with large nucleus (basophilic).

questions.text: Identify the structure marked in the given image?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Terminal bronchioles

Explanation:

  • Terminal bronchioles differ from larger bronchi as they are devoid of cartilage in their walls.
  • The ciliated cells are still present in terminal bronchioles, but their abundance is reduced.
  • Additionally, terminal bronchioles exhibit alveolar outgrowths, marking the transition to structures involved in gas exchange.

 

Respiratory bronchus (Option A):

  • Respiratory bronchioles have alveoli budding directly from their walls. This is a distinctive feature that indicates their role in gas exchange.
  • Epithelium may become more cuboidal, eventually transitioning to simple squamous epithelium in the alveoli.
  • Similar to terminal bronchioles, respiratory bronchioles lack cartilage in their walls.

Alveolar sac (Option C):

  • Alveolar sacs are composed of clusters of alveoli, which are small, balloon-like structures.
  • Alveolar walls are extremely thin to facilitate efficient gas exchange.

Intrapulmonary bronchus (Option D):

  • Intrapulmonary bronchi have smooth muscle in their walls, which helps regulate airflow.
  • Goblet cells, found in the epithelium of intrapulmonary bronchi, secrete mucus to aid in capturing particles and facilitating their expulsion from the respiratory tract.
  • Cartilage found in the intrapulmonary bronchus helps maintain the shape of the bronchi, preserving the integrity of the airway structure.

questions.text: Which of the following is the lining epithelium of the trachea?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Pseudostratified ciliated columnar

Explanation:

The trachea is lined by pseudostratified ciliated columnar epithelium with goblet cells. This specialized epithelium plays a key role in:

  • Mucociliary clearance: The cilia help move mucus and trapped particles upward toward the pharynx.
  • Protection: Goblet cells secrete mucus that traps dust, bacteria, and other particles.

Respiratory Epithelium: 

Features of the various parts of the respiratory passages:

Simple squamous epithelium (Option A): Found in alveoli, allowing gas exchange, not in the trachea.

Transitional epithelium (Option B): Found in the urinary system (bladder, ureters, renal pelvis), not in the trachea.

Stratified squamous epithelium (Option C): Found in the oropharynx, laryngopharynx, and vocal cords, but not in the normal trachea (except in chronic irritation like smoking, where metaplasia can occur).

questions.text: Which hormone is produced from the layer marked in the given image?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A)

Explanation:

  • The marked area is the adrenal medulla, which is responsible for producing catecholamines like norepinephrine and epinephrine.

Adrenal Cortex

Network of intercalated cells

Adrenal medulla:

  • Norepinephrine

  • Small amounts of dopamine
  • Carbohydrate and fat metabolisms
  • Fight or flight responses

Specialized sympathetic ganglion

Clumps and strands of chromaffin cells

 

(Options A, B, and C)

questions.text:
Match the receptors with their correct function:


	
		
			
			1. Ruffini corpuscle
			
			
			A. Vibration
			
		
		
			
			2. Merkel cells
			
			
			B. Sustained pressure
			
		
		
			
			3. Pacinian corpuscle
			
			
			C. Stretching
			
		
		
			
			4. Meissner’s corpuscle
			
			
			D. Fine touch
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - 1C, 2B, 3A, 4D:

  • Ruffini corpuscle (1C): These are mechanoreceptors that respond to the stretching of the skin, which is crucial for the perception of the direction and amount of stretch.
  • Merkel cells (2B): These are slowly adapting receptors that are sensitive to sustained pressure and texture, providing fine details about objects touching the skin.
  • Pacinian corpuscle (3A): These are rapidly adapting receptors that detect vibration and deep pressure, essential for sensing rapid changes in the environment.
  • Meissner’s corpuscle (4D): These receptors are sensitive to fine touch and low-frequency vibration, allowing the detection of textures and slight pressure changes.

 

Incorrect Options:

  • Options B, C and D are marked incorrect.

questions.text: Identify the markers in the given slide:

choices.text: A- Eccrine sweat gland, B- Arrector pilorum, C- Sebaceous gland, D- Apocrine gland
A- Arrector pilorum, B- Eccrine sweat gland, C- Sebaceous gland, D- Apocrine gland
A- Eccrine sweat gland, B- Arrector pilorum, C- Apocrine gland, D-Sebaceous gland
A- Sebaceous gland, B- Apocrine gland, C- Eccrine sweat gland, D- Arrector pilorum

questions.solution:
Correct Option A - A- Eccrine sweat gland, B- Arrector pilorum, C- Sebaceous gland, D- Apocrine gland:

A - Eccrine Sweat Gland: Eccrine sweat glands are responsible for thermoregulation and are found throughout the body, primarily in the palms, soles, and forehead. They are characterized by their tubular structure and are often found deep in the dermis.

B - Arrector Pilorum: These are small muscles attached to hair follicles. When they contract, they cause the hair to stand up, commonly known as piloerection. They are typically found alongside hair follicles.

C - Sebaceous Gland: Sebaceous glands are responsible for producing sebum, an oily substance that lubricates the skin and hair. They are usually associated with hair follicles and appear as small clusters of cells in the dermis.

D - Apocrine Gland: Apocrine sweat glands are primarily found in the axillary and genital regions. They secrete a thicker, milky fluid into hair follicles and are involved in scent production. These glands are larger than eccrine glands and have a more complex structure.

 

Incorrect Options:

Options B, C, and D: These options are incorrectly matched.

questions.text: Histological section is given below. Identify the marked cell.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Purkinje cell

Explanation:


The marked area in the image is a Purkinje cell.

The cerebellar cortex consists of the following three distinct layers:

 

Layers of the cerebellar cortex

Molecular (plexiform) layer

(Options A, B)

Purkinje cell layer

Granular layer

(Option D)

It primarily contains numerous dendritic branches from Purkinje cells, with relatively few widely spaced nerve cells.

It consists of a single row of large flask-shaped cells, the Purkinje cells.

The inner granular layer is made up of many closely packed small granule cells, along with a few larger Golgi cells.

These nerve cells are of two types:

(a) Basket cells

(b) Stellate cells.

The axons of Purkinje cells are the only output from the cerebellar cortex and have an inhibitory effect on the intracerebellar nuclei.

Golgi cells are inhibitory while the granular cells are excitatory.

 

Among the five types of intrinsic neurons (Basket cells, Stellate cells, Purkinje cells, Granule cells and Golgi cells)- All are inhibitory except granule cells.

questions.text: Identify the lymphatic structure from the histology section given below?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Thymus

 

Explanation:

 

The image shows a distinct lobulated structure with a darker outer cortex and a lighter inner medulla. This is characteristic of the thymus.

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

Parts of the Thymus:

  1. Cortex:
    • The outer, more densely packed region of the thymus.
    • Filled with immature T cells (thymocytes), undergoing differentiation and maturation as they move towards the medulla.
    • The cortex contains thymic nurse cells that support the maturing thymocytes.
    • T cells express surface markers (like TCR, CD3, CD4, and CD8) during maturation.
    • Macrophages are present to phagocytose apoptotic T cells, which fail to mature properly.
  2. Medulla:
    • The inner, less densely populated region.
    • Dominated by epithelial cells with pale-staining nuclei and large cytoplasm.
    • Contains Hassall's corpuscles, concentric structures made of keratinized epithelial cells, involved in T cell regulation.
    • Dendritic cells and macrophages in the medulla present self-antigens to maturing T cells, ensuring the elimination of self-reactive cells to prevent autoimmunity.

Histology of the Thymus:

  • Epithelial Framework: Throughout the thymus, epithelial cells provide a structural scaffold for lymphocyte development and produce hormones like thymopoietin, which regulate T cell maturation and proliferation.
  • It is divided into lobules by connective tissue septa.
  • A protective blood-thymus barrier prevents antigens from entering, safeguarding T cell maturation.

With age, the thymus undergoes involution, where lymphoid tissue is replaced by fat, but it continues to produce mature T cells.

 


 

Tonsil (Option A): Tonsils contain lymphoid follicles with germinal centers. The histology of tonsils features these follicles, unlike the thymus.

 

Lymph node (Option B):

Lymph nodes also have lymphoid follicles but have a more defined capsule, cortex, paracortex, and medulla.

Spleen (Option C):

The spleen has a characteristic red pulp (containing blood) and white pulp (containing lymphocytes)

questions.text: Which layer is indicated in the provided histological section?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Inner plexiform layer:

  • The inner plexiform layer is the layer in the retina where synapses occur between bipolar cells, amacrine cells, and ganglion cells.
  • It is responsible for processing and integrating visual signals before transmitting them to the ganglion cell layer.

Incorrect Options - A, C, and D are incorrect. Refer to the explanation of the correct answer.
